sect1.title: My Memories
sect1.para: I was born in 1967 in Omaha, Nebraska. Elizabeth Nevin Conneely was 77 years old and lived on Samson's Harbor Farm in Mechanicsvillle, Maryland. Before I record my personal memories, I will provide a bit of background, although I will save more of her biographical details for later. In 1967, Gram lived by herself in the farmhouse and the Nolans and the Plowdens also lived on the Farm. William Nolan, who had managed the farming for Gram since the late 1930's , died in 1967. York Plowden was hit by a car and killed in 1968, although the Plowdens may no longer have been working on the farm by then. Gram's oldest child, John Gundry Jennings lived in Huntington, WV and Nanny and my parents lived in Omaha, Nebraska.

The following events obiously occurred long before my first memories, but I have scanned my childhood photo album and have my Mom's notes to guide me. I was born on November 24th and baptized in the Catholic church in December. Gram travelled to Omaha in March 1968 and I met Gram for the first time. I'm not sure what brought Gram to Omaha, but while she was there, I was baptized for the second time, this time in the Presbyterian Church. Gram was a Presbyterian, and either didn't know about my Catholic baptism, or didn't care and wanted the job done according to her standards. I will have to ask my parents. My first visit to the farm was in September, 1968 and my first Christmas on the farm was in 1970.

The first visit to Samson's Harbor that I actually remember was probably in the summer of 1972, and I really can't say that I have any specific memories of Gram. What I do remember is Dad and Aunt Kathy putting rows of well-rings into the beach to prevent erosion and a visit to the Leonardtown Volunteer Fire Department's Summer Carnival. Perhaps it is from this visit that I remember sitting in the front seat of Gram's Ford as she drove down the driveway. I remember keeping an eye on the driveway looking for box turtles, and Gram singing a song describing the features of the the farm that we were passing. "Here we go past Gant's Lot, Gant's Lot, Gant's Lot â€¦"

We moved from Omaha to Maryland in August 1973. I believe that Gram had some health care that promted Nanny and Dad to move east to be closer to Gram. Nanny found a job at Johns Hopkins Medical Campus in Baltimore, and Dad was hired as an art teacher at Thomas Stone High School in Waldorf, Maryland. We lived on the Farm from August until December while Mom and Dad looked for a house to buy. Considering I spent more than three months in daily contact with Gram, I actually have very few memories of her. Like many people who lived through the Depression, she didn't throw much away. When she was finished with a small tub of margarine, she would wash it out and save it for later use. One warm day, probably shortly after we moved in, I noticed stink bugs climbing on the screen door on the front porch. I was fascinated by these ugly insects that gave off an unpleasant odor when you poked them. Gram noticed my interest in the bugs. I asked her if I could have a jar to collect the stink bugs and she brought out a stack of margarine tubs.
Gram was 8? years old at this time
